doc.title: JPM | Legrand onto Analyst Focus list, European Car Sales
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/JPM Industrial Strength Morning Messages Legrand onto Analyst Focus list European Car SalesJPM Industrial Strength Morni_2025-08-29

passages.text: Today: Earnings: OCI NA

- LEGRAND ONTO ANALYST FOCUS LIST, ABB, SCHNEIDER TO NEUTRAL: Phil Buller follows up yesterday's Siemens note (HERE) with a note that moves the rest of the large cap Electricals onto active recommendations. Legrand is most preferred and goes onto the Analyst Focus List while ABB and Schneider are both rated Neutral. Core message is that the Data Center market remains a strong and sustained growth driver. That said, it is reflected well in consensus forecasts. We see upside to Legrand consensus from a nascent recovery in European residential construction with the option of a US office recovery to come. We are not significantly different to consensus for either ABB or Schneider with our forecasts - hence the Neutral rating. We note that ABB is going to spin its Robotics business and is hosting a Capital Markets Day on Nov \(18^{\mathrm{th}}\) . There is no Capital markets Day in the Schneider calendar and we believe that the Company would benefit from such an event to reassure investors that there is potential for margin gearing in the business. NOTE IS HERE

- We are mindful of the "wood for the trees" idiom when it comes to the electricals subgroup; the multi-year out-growth of electrical equipment investment versus GDP is almost as certain as death and taxes, but there are important near-term factors to overlay which drive our ratings and Dec 2026 price targets. We see the most upside risk to consensus at Legrand and in Siemens' SI division, based on our analysis of DC, US office, resi, and discrete automation, as explored herein. We are OW Legrand (from NR) with a PT of €165, which we transfer to Phil Buller and add to our AFL. We are Neutral ABB (from NR) (CHF 55) and Neutral Schneider (from NR) (€220), having published on Siemens at OW (€300) yesterday

- EUROPEAN AUTOS: We received data on European Auto sales yesterday and Jose has a note out this morning going through the data (HERE). Germany and Spain were relative bright spots while the UK, Italy and France saw car sales decline. Germany is encouraging because it offers another data point implying an economic recovery (remember Holcim management comments from the dinner re Germans are getting more confident). Brand wise, BYD and SAIC saw very strong sales growth (from a low base) - but it looks like Tesla is the main share donor. BMW continues to outperform Mercedes, VW and Renault are performing best in the mass segments. It would be nice to get comfort on LCV sales for Renault to give confidence it can recover from the recent profit warning.

- Passenger car sales across the five major European countries were up \(2\%\) y/y to 738k units in July'25, and down \(21\%\) vs pre-COVID-19 levels of July'19. Volumes were up \(11.1\%\) y/y in Germany, UK volumes were down \(5\%\) y/y and Italian volumes were down \(5.1\%\) y/y. Volumes fell by \(7.7\%\) y/y in France and rose by \(17.1\%\) y/y in Spain. Chinese OEMs market share has increased from \(4.8\%\) in July'24 to \(4.9\%\) in July'25 and their YTD market share is around \(5.09\%\) . Tesla sales fell by \(41\%\) y/y compared to July'24, making it the seventh consecutive month of falling sales yoy.

- European production, excluding Russia, has been experiencing a slowdown. After growing by \(13.3\%\) in 2023, it declined by \(5.9\%\) in FY 2024. In Q1 2025, production fell by \(5.2\%\) y/y, followed by a \(1.3\%\) decrease in Q2. The latest S&P data indicates that production is anticipated to decrease by \(1.7\%\) in Q3 and by \(2.1\%\) Q4. In 2025, production experienced declines of \(10.8\%\) in January, \(10.1\%\) in February, and \(6.9\%\) in April. Conversely, March, May, and June saw increases of \(0.9\%\) , \(0.5\%\) , and \(1.6\%\) , respectively. For Europe, S&P predicts a \(2.7\%\) decrease in production for FY 2025 and a \(0.2\%\) decrease for FY 2026.

- Pricing update. July ICE pricing power in Europe remains disciplined, slightly stronger than the trend seen in previous months, despite the recent concerns over discount pressure in Europe. Incentives for premium models have been increasing in the last six months and have started to normalize in the last three months. Price competition is more focused in the leasing BEV market. We believe the next few months will be critical to follow how the pricing patterns unfold in

European Capital Goods - Near- term matters in the multi- year electricals trade- Phil Buller hereWe are mindful of the "wood for the trees" idiom when it comes to the electricals subgroup; the multi- year out- growth of electrical equipment investment versus GDP is almost as certain as death and taxes, but there are important near- term factors to overlay which drive our ratings and Dec 2026 price targets. We see the most upside risk to consensus at Legrand and in Siemens' SI division, based on our analysis of DC, US office, resi, and discrete automation, as explored herein. We are OW Legrand (from NR) with a PT of 165, which we transfer to Phil Buller and add to our AFL. We are Neutral ABB (from NR) (CHF 55) and Neutral Schneider (from NR) (220), having published on Siemens at OW (300) yesterday (link).

Lanxess - Model Update- Chetan Udeshi hereWe have updated our model to reflect 2Q results earlier this month, with which the company also lowered its FY25 adj EBITDA guidance. We have cut FY25E/26E sales by \(6\% /7\%\) and adj EBITDA by \(7\% /10\%\) to reflect the continued weak demand environment thus far and some pricing pressure from more competitive Chinese imports in some of the company's product segments, along with incremental FX headwinds. Our new FY25E adj EBITDA of 528m (- 14% YoY; and around - 10% YoY organic) is close to the lower- end of the company's guidance range of 520- 580m with our new FY26E adj EBITDA of 554m (+5% YoY). In line with lower estimates, we trim our Dec 2026- end PT to 21 (22).

FLSmidth - Post Q2'25 Sell- side meeting - Key take- aways- Chittra C Sinha hereFLSmidth (FLS) hosted a sell- side meeting this morning post the group's Q2'25 results with CEO Mikko Keto. FLS provided more colour on each of the three new divisions: Products, Service and PC&V. The biggest driver of higher profitability will be the Products business and here management is taking cost out over the next six months. FLS will be holding a CMD in March 2026, where we should get more colour on the group strategy now as a Mining pure play. We summarise the key take- aways here.

Eiffage - Model Update- Elodie Rall hereWe update our model following Eiffage's H1 results (link to our first take). Our 25E EBIT decreases slightly as we increase our estimate for the Holding level loss, with our Contracting EBIT increasing and Concessions EBIT very slightly decreasing. We also incorporate revised guidance for the impact of France's surtax in 2025, underpinning the increase in our 25E Net Income. Our Dec- 26 PT is unchanged at 136, now implying 25% upside to the current share price, despite our increased estimates as we MTM in our WACC for interest rates.

APAC Energy Transition - Tightness and Tribulations: Ten Fresh Takes on Clean Energy Supply- Alan Hon hereThe road to a clean energy future is long (and uncertain). While the energy transition remains an overarching theme, history has shown that renewable energy build- out at scale does not necessarily translate into returns at all points of the value chain. Industry cycles, technological advancement, and geopolitics all come into play. In this report, we give10 answers to questions relating to the transition on three main Topics: 1) Which transition value chains are in supply tightness or emerging as important ones? 2) Where are geopolitical risks less well understood? 3) Which transition technologies will be the next game changers? JPM- covered stocks that emerge as our top picks include: Bannerman Energy (BMN), CATL- A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung Heavy, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga.
Use the links below to jump straight to each section: Industrials Overnight Global Industrials Research Global Macro Research Save the Date: J.P. Morgan Events J.P. Morgan Industrials Contacts
US Indices :S&P500 +0.3%, Ind'l Machinery - 0.5%, Ind'l Conglomerates +0.3%, Constr & Farm +0.2%, Aero +0.5%,Autos - 1%.
